title: Thymus, Tonsils, and Reticulo-Endothelial System
subject: Histology and Immunology
description: Questions about the structure, function, and cellular components of the thymus gland, tonsils, and reticulo-endothelial system (RES).

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of the thymus gland?
questions.explanation: The thymus gland is primarily responsible for the proliferation and differentiation of T-lymphocytes, which are critical for cellular immunity.

questions.questionText: Where is the thymus gland located in the body?
questions.explanation: The thymus gland is located behind the sternum, in the mediastinum.

questions.questionText: What happens to the thymus gland after puberty?
options: It becomes a secondary lymphoid organ
questions.explanation: The thymus gland undergoes atrophy after puberty, reducing in size and activity.

questions.questionText: What is the structure of the thymus gland described as?
questions.explanation: The thymus is a single bi-lobed gland, consisting of two lobes divided into lobules.

questions.questionText: What forms the capsule of the thymus gland?
questions.explanation: The capsule of the thymus is thin and formed of collagen fibers and fibroblasts.

questions.questionText: What is the role of trabeculae in the thymus gland?
options: Divide the gland into lobes and lobules
questions.correctAnswer: Divide the gland into lobes and lobules
questions.explanation: Trabeculae are thin structures made of collagen fibers and fibroblasts that divide the thymus into lobes and lobules.

questions.questionText: What stains the reticular network in the thymus gland?
questions.explanation: The reticular network in the thymus is stained with silver (Ag).

questions.questionText: Which zone of the thymus gland contains more lymphocytes, making it appear darker?
questions.explanation: The cortex of the thymus is darker due to the presence of many lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: Which cells are absent in the thymus cortex?
questions.explanation: The thymus cortex lacks B-lymphocytes and plasma cells, focusing on T-lymphocyte development.

questions.questionText: What is a characteristic feature of the thymus medulla?
questions.explanation: Hassall’s corpuscles are found in the medulla and are formed of concentric layers of degenerated reticular cells.

questions.questionText: What are Hassall’s corpuscles composed of?
options: Concentric layers of degenerated reticular cells
questions.correctAnswer: Concentric layers of degenerated reticular cells
questions.explanation: Hassall’s corpuscles are rounded, acidophilic, hyaline masses formed of concentric layers of degenerated reticular cells.

questions.questionText: What is the embryonic origin of epithelial reticular cells in the thymus?
questions.explanation: Epithelial reticular cells in the thymus are endodermal in origin.

questions.questionText: Which feature distinguishes epithelial reticular cells in the thymus?
questions.explanation: Epithelial reticular cells have tonofilaments and desmosomes, characteristic of epithelial cells, and do not form fibers.

questions.questionText: What do epithelial reticular cells in the thymus secrete?
questions.explanation: Epithelial reticular cells secrete thymic hormones that stimulate T-lymphocyte maturation.

questions.questionText: Which thymic hormone is responsible for stimulating T-lymphocyte maturation?
questions.explanation: Thymopoietin is one of the thymic hormones that stimulates the maturation and activity of T-lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: What is the role of macrophages in the thymus?
questions.explanation: Macrophages in the thymus phagocytose degenerating thymocytes and foreign substances.

questions.questionText: Which component is part of the blood-thymic barrier?
questions.explanation: The blood-thymic barrier includes a continuous endothelium lining the blood capillaries, preventing premature exposure of T-lymphocytes to antigens.

questions.questionText: Where is the blood-thymic barrier located in the thymus?
questions.explanation: The blood-thymic barrier is present only in the cortex of the thymus, not in the medulla.

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of the blood-thymic barrier?
options: Allow T-lymphocytes to multiply free of antigens
questions.correctAnswer: Allow T-lymphocytes to multiply free of antigens
questions.explanation: The blood-thymic barrier protects immature T-lymphocytes from premature exposure to circulating antigens.

questions.questionText: Why is the medulla of the thymus paler than the cortex?
options: Fewer lymphocytes and more reticular cells
questions.correctAnswer: Fewer lymphocytes and more reticular cells
questions.explanation: The medulla appears paler because it contains fewer lymphocytes and more reticular cells compared to the cortex.

questions.questionText: What is the role of thymic humoral factor?
questions.explanation: Thymic humoral factor is one of the thymic hormones that stimulates T-lymphocyte maturation.

questions.questionText: What is the function of thymocytes in the thymus?
questions.explanation: Thymocytes are immature cells in the thymus that develop into mature T-lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: Where are tonsils located in the body?
options: In the connective tissue lamina propria under epithelium
questions.correctAnswer: In the connective tissue lamina propria under epithelium
questions.explanation: Tonsils are located in the connective tissue lamina propria under the epithelium, forming a ring around the oral and nasal pharynx.

questions.questionText: What is the composition of lymphatic tissue in tonsils?
questions.explanation: Tonsils consist of lymphatic tissue formed of lymphatic nodules (often with germinal centers) and diffuse lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: How many types of tonsils are described?
questions.explanation: The three types of tonsils are palatine, lingual, and pharyngeal.

questions.questionText: Where are palatine tonsils located?
questions.explanation: Palatine tonsils are a pair located in the lateral part of the oropharynx.

questions.questionText: What type of epithelium covers palatine tonsils?
questions.explanation: Palatine tonsils are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, which dips to form crypts.

questions.questionText: What is a characteristic feature of palatine tonsils?
questions.explanation: Palatine tonsils have an incomplete capsule from below and are covered by epithelium that forms crypts.

questions.questionText: What is the location of the pharyngeal tonsil?
questions.explanation: The pharyngeal tonsil is a single tonsil located in the superior posterior part of the nasopharynx.

questions.questionText: What type of epithelium covers the pharyngeal tonsil?
options: Pseudostratified columnar ciliated with goblet cells
questions.correctAnswer: Pseudostratified columnar ciliated with goblet cells
questions.explanation: The pharyngeal tonsil is covered with pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium with goblet cells.

questions.questionText: What condition results from hypertrophy of the pharyngeal tonsil?
questions.explanation: Hypertrophy of the pharyngeal tonsil results in a condition known as adenoids.

questions.questionText: Where are lingual tonsils located?
questions.explanation: Lingual tonsils are located at the posterior 1/3 of the tongue.

questions.questionText: What is a feature of lingual tonsils?
options: Mucous glands open into bases of crypts
questions.correctAnswer: Mucous glands open into bases of crypts
questions.explanation: Lingual tonsils have crypts, and mucous glands open into the bases of these crypts.

questions.questionText: What is the reticulo-endothelial system (RES)?
options: Highly phagocytic cells in most organs
questions.correctAnswer: Highly phagocytic cells in most organs
questions.explanation: The reticulo-endothelial system (RES) consists of highly phagocytic cells present in most organs of the body.

questions.questionText: What is the origin of cells in the reticulo-endothelial system?
questions.explanation: Cells of the RES, such as macrophages, develop from blood monocytes.

questions.questionText: Which stain is used to identify cells of the reticulo-endothelial system?
questions.explanation: Cells of the RES are specially stained with trypan blue, a vital stain.

questions.questionText: What is a characteristic feature of RES cells under electron microscopy?
questions.explanation: RES cells, such as macrophages, show many lysosomes, Golgi, phagosomes, and residual bodies under electron microscopy.

questions.questionText: What is a key function of the reticulo-endothelial system?
questions.explanation: The primary function of the RES is phagocytosis of foreign particles.

questions.questionText: Which cells of the RES act as antigen-presenting cells?
questions.explanation: Macrophages in the RES help lymphocytes by acting as antigen-presenting cells, liberating antigens for immune recognition.

questions.questionText: Which cells of the RES are found in the liver?
questions.explanation: Kupffer’s cells are macrophages of the reticulo-endothelial system found in the liver.

questions.questionText: Which cells of the RES are located in the brain?
questions.explanation: Microglia are the macrophages of the reticulo-endothelial system found in the brain.

questions.questionText: What is a characteristic of RES cells in culture?
questions.explanation: RES cells, such as macrophages, adhere to glass in culture, a characteristic feature.

questions.questionText: What can modulate the activity of RES cells?
questions.explanation: RES cells can be inhibited or activated by lymphokines produced by T-lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: Which cells of the RES are found in the skin?
questions.explanation: Langerhans cells are part of the reticulo-endothelial system and are found in the skin.

questions.questionText: What is a feature of the mucous glands in palatine tonsils?
questions.explanation: The mucous glands in palatine tonsils do not open into crypts and are frequently inflamed.
